These individuals are truly masters of deception and manipulation of commerce, working behind the scenes to direct the populace and maintain their city.

monster.description:
In Antronec's sewers, these vile monstrosities roam, relishing in the abundance of waste and smaller prey. Some researchers presume that this unholy mixture of dung beetle and centipede was created by a mage or deity striving to inspire nightmares. It is uniquely adept at navigating the underground and often-poisonous sewer system, as many adventurers have discovered. In fact, some adventuring agencies consider slaying a scarapit to be the deciding factor between an adventurer and a thrill-seeker.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 340 (Third Party)

monster.name: Seed Coin
monster.languages: understands Common but doesn't speak it

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: The seed coin is indistinguishable from a normal copper piece. However, a creature that has truesight sees a deep red aura radiating from the seed coin, and a creature within 30 feet of it that is under the effect of a detect poison and disease spell senses the insidicous nature of the seed coin and knows it is a plant creature.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: The seed coin doesn't require sleep. If the seed coin spends 1 minute in direct sunlight or a creature spends 1 hour in direct sunlight while the seed coin is on the creature's person, the seed coin receives enough nourishment to sustain itself for one day. When the seed coin dies, itr becomes an ordinary copper piece.

action.name: Infestation
action.text:
Melee Weapon Attack: +0 to hit, reach 0 ft., one humanoid that has the seed coin on its person. Hit: The creature must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or its mind becomes imperceptibly infected with a disease until the seed coin is no longer on the creature's person or the creature dies. Creatures immune to the charmed condition are immune to this disease, and a creature that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to this disease for the next 30 days. The seed coin's influence invades a diseased creature's mind, killing the creature in a number of hours equal to 1d12 + the creature's Wisdom score, unless the disease is removed. In half that time, the creature becomes charmed for the rest of the duration and refuses to part with the seed coin.
If a diseased creature dies while the seed coin is on its person, it immediately regains all its hit points and becomes a seed coin pollinator, as the seed coin takes over its body. The seed coin doesn't gain access to the creature's knowledge, class features, or proficiencies while controlling a creature in this way. This infestation lasts until the seed coin pollinator dies, killing the seed coin.

monster.description:
Out of all the strange plants across the Material Plane, perhaps the most insidious among them is the seed coin. Taking the appearance of a humble copper piece, or occasionally a silver, they easily pass from hand to hand in marketplaces. When they take root, they develop into their second stage of growth, infested pollinators that only appear human. These walking 'flowers' latch onto and collectively build the third stage, a germination stall, which coordinates the coins and pollinators to further expand their reach.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 340 (Third Party)

monster.name: Seed Coin Pollinator
monster.languages: The languages its host knew in life

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: The pollinator is indistinguishable from a normal commoner, and it appears and sounds exactly like the creature it was before becoming infested. However, a creature that has truesight sees a deep red aura radiating from the pollinator, and a creature within 30 feet of it that is under the effect of a detect poison and disease spell sensees the insidious nature of the pollinator and knows it is a plant creature.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: The pollinator doesn't require sleep. If the pollinator spends 1 hour in direct sunlight, it receives enough nourishment to sustain itself for one day. When the pollinator dies, it becomes an ordinary human corpse.

action.name: Dagger
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) piercing damage.

action.name: Coin Spray
action.text: The pollinator hurls a flurry of seed coins at one creature it can see within 10 feet of it. The target must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (4d4) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, one of the seed coins gets lodged on the target's body (for example, in a pokcet or fold in its clothing).

monster.description:
Once a seed coin has fully taken root in its host's mind, it begins to burrow into their flesh. From there, it begins to expand its vines through the veins of the deceased creature, utilizing the abundant moisture, nutrients, and direct access to the body's brain and lungs. Once it has spread, it puppets the form with these vines, though the bulk of it resides in the unmoving lungs and skull cavity.
This rapid growth strengthens the body's cell walls, making them heardier and more plant-like below the skin's surface. The appearance changes little, but the pollinator is most certainly a plant and not a humanoid.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 341 (Third Party)

monster.name: Germination Stall
monster.languages: the languages its staff knew in life

trait.name: Alluring Affluence
trait.text: Whenever a humanoid ends its turn within 60 feet of the stall, it must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has no hint that it is gradually fallling under the effects of the stall's enchantment. If a creature succeeds on three of these saves, it is immune to this effect for the next 24 hours. If the crature fails three of these saves, it becomes charmed by the stall and must use all its movement on its turn to get as close to the stall as possible. The effect lasts for 24 hours or until the stall dies, is on a different plane of existence than the target, or ends the effect on the creature as a bonus action.

trait.name: Dedicated Staff
trait.text: The stall comprises a staff of 5 (2d4) seed coin pollinators. This staff collectively shares the stall's Innate Spellcasting and Magic Resistance traits, they can't willingly move more than 150 feet away from the staff, and they seek to defend the stall at all costs, including to their own peril. Some of the stall's effects can use a member or members of its staff as the point of origin.

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: The stall is indistinguishable from a normal merchant stall. However, a creature that has true-sight sees a deep red aura radiating from the stall, and a creature within 30 feet of it that is under the effect of a detect poison and disease spell senses the insidious nature of the stall and knows it is a plant creature.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
trait.text:
The stall's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 15). The stall can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
At will: detect, detect thoughts, prestigitation 3/day each: comprehend languages, suggestion, unseen servant 1/day each: create food and water, creation, geas, mass suggestion

trait.name: Magic Resistance
trait.text: The stall has advanatage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: The stall doesn't require sleep. If the stall spends 1 hours in direct sunlight, it receives enough nourishment to sustain itself for one day. If the stall dies, it decomposes and is reduces to dirt within 7 days.

action.name: Enthralling Vines
action.text: The stall causes dark, creeping vines to protrude from itself and its staff, lashing out at creatures nearby. Each creature of the stall's choice within 10 feet of it or a member of its staff must succeed on a DC 14 Strength saving throw or be restrained by the vines for 1 minute. While restrainerd in this way, a creature has disadvantage on saving throws against the stall's Alluring Affluence. A creature restrained by the vines can use its action to make a DC 14 Strength check, freeing itself on a success. These vines disappear if the stall dies, or if it uses the action again. It can also choose to end the efffect early on any number of restrained creatures it chooses as a bonus action.

action.name: Hostile Takeover
action.text: The stall attempts to magically compel one creature charmed by it that is within 5 feet of the stall or a member of its staff to swallow a seed coin. The target must make a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target swallows the coin and is subjected to the seed coin's Infestation. When subjected to the effect in this way, the diseased creature is killed in a number of hours equal to half its Wisdom score, unless the disease is removed. If the target successfull saves against this effect or the effect ends for it, it regurgitates the coin and is no longer charmed by the stall, and it is immune to the stall's Alluring Affluence for the next 24 hours.

monster.description:
It's not entirely clear how seed coin pollinators manage to coalesce and combine into a germination stall, as it's never been witnessed directly. What has been recorded is that by all indications, a germination stall looks like almost every other merchant stall around it. They often have their own quirks, based on the appearance of their staff members, which are their pollinators. They rarely make any sales, as their inventory seems deliberately unappealing. Instead, the pollinators channel energy from the stall to produce seed coins which can be slipped into pockets, left on the street, or offered as alms to the poor.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 342 (Third Party)

monster.name: Blodmire Treant

trait.name: Bloodmire Adaptation
trait.text: The treant is immune to the diseases described in the Bloodmire Diseases table.

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the treant remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal Bloodmire Tree.

trait.name: Siege Monster
trait.text: The treant deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The treant makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (3d6+4) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Mud Ball
action.text: Ranged weapon attack: +7 to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. Hit: 20 (3d10+4) bludgeoning damage, and the target's speed is halves until the start of the treant's next turn.

action.name: Animate Blood
action.text:
The treant magically animates a pool of blood it can see within 60 feet of it. The blood congeals into a viscous form and has the statistics of a gelatinous cube, except its Ooze Cube, Psuedopod, and Engult trait and action options deal necrotic damage instead of acid damage, and its Transparent trait doesn't function unless it's in blood or bloodwater.
The animated blood acts as an ally of the treant. The blood remains animate for 8 hours until it does; until the treant dies or is more than 120 feet from the blood; or until the treant takes a bonus action to turn it back into an inanimate pool of blood.

monster.description:
The Syre Wood was home to numerous great trees and treants, but the swiftness of the Legion's assault left the forest's defense in the hands of Syre and his sprites.
As such, the blood of Malfuriel has rapidly tainted the various treants of the swamp just as it altered the other wildlife. Those unlucky enough to draw a bloodmire treant's ire will face all of nature's wrath as well as the foul blood magic of Malfuriel, as these cursed treants possess the ability to animate pools of bloodwater into ooze-like forms as an additional means of defense.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 344 (Third Party)

monster.description:
The Crimson Legionnaires are a swift, decisive, and efficient unit of infantry. In stark contrast to typical imps, Crimson Legion imps are zealous and obedient followers, known throughout the Lower Planes for their stubborn devotion to Malfuriel. With invisibility and silvered tongues, the art of war is second nature to them, and ensures that any battlefield conflict is skewed in their favor. They make frequent use of their shapechanging, becoming rats, hawks, and centipedes in order to scout, spy, or conceal their true numbers.
Made larger by fiendish blood magic, these imps are otherwise similar in appearance to their lesser brethren. Red skin in various shades, poison-dripping scorpion tail, bat-like wings and unique patterns of horns upon their heads all serve as identifying features.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 344 (Third Party)

With translucent red skin, the giant blood eels of the Bloodmire are nearly impossible to detect as they traverse the deep pools of bloodwater. Naturalists are unsure of exactly how the eels came to dwell in the swamp, but attempts to research them more fully or retrieve a specimen has resulted in numerous vanished expeditions.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 345 (Third Party)

Empowered by the sheer volume of slow-moving blood present in the swampland formerly known as the Syre Wood, giant mosquitoes are a constant threat to travelers and denizens alike. - A stream of blood opens up on the ground originating at a point Malfuriel chooses within 60 feet of him. The stream is 30 feet long, 5 feet wide, and 5 feet deep. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, a creature moves to the nearest unoccupied space of its choice outside the stream. On a failed save, the creature falls into the stream and takes 7 (2d6) necrotic damage. A creature that starts its turn in the stream must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become diseased (see the Bloodmire Diseases table).
- A pillar of unholy flame bursts from the ground. Each creature in a 5-foot radius, 60-foot-high cylinder centered on a point Malfuriel chooses within 60 feet of him must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 (2d6) fire damage and 7 (2d6) necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

monster.description:
Malfuriel was once an ardent enforcer of the heavens: charged with punishing bigots and heretics. But time's passing led him to take satisfactionâ€”then pleasureâ€” from inflicting pain. He became a sadistic torturer and was exiled from the Upper Planes: a fallen planetar.
When the forces of hell offered him the opportunity to lead a legion and inflict wanton suffering on his choice of targets, Malfuriel accepted the bargain, becoming a devil in the process. After several successful campaigns of slaughter and torture, Malfuriel's Crimson Legion became a renowned and unstoppable force of destruction. With bruised, pale green skin and a multitude of open cuts slowly oozing blood, Malfuriel's hulking form is appropriately intimidating and only subtly recognizable as once angelic. His once white-feathered wings are now stained and dripping crimson. Freed from Syre's cursed blade, his boundless fury is free once more to raze all opposition.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 346 (Third Party)

If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Lothrem's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.text:

The wall is 20 feet high and blocks line of sight. Each creature in the area must make a DC 25 Dexterity saving throw. The wall remains until the end of Lothrem's next turn, at which point it withers and disappears. A creature restrained in the wall or one that is within 5 feet of the creature can use its action to make a DC 19 Strength check, freeing the creature on a success. For the duration, the area is difficult terrain, and when a creatures moves into or within the area, it takes 9 (2d8) piercing damage for every 5 feet it travels.

action.name: Change Shape

In a new form, Lothrem retains their own alignment, hit points, hit dice, ability to speak, proficiencies, Legendary Resistance, lair actions, and Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma scores, as well as this action. Lothrem's statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendarry actions of that form.

legendary.name: Lair Actions

For 1 minute, the area is under the effects of the entangle spell. This effect ends early if Lothrem uses this lair action again or if they die.

legendary.name: Regional Effects
legendary.text:
The region containing Lothrem's lair is warped by their draconic magic, which creates one or more of the following effects: - Each creature that has the ability to cast at least one spell can cast the druidcraft cantrip at will while within 6 miles of Lothrem's lair. - The weather within 6 miles of the lair is substantially affected by Lothrem's current state of mind (see Lothrem's Mood & Weather table).
Ivy and other vines are prevalent on stone structures within 1 mile of Lothrem's lair, reinforcing the structures and protecting them against the elements. In addition, while Lothrem is within their lair, grass and flowers continously growth underneath them, as if under the effects of the druidcraft spell.

monster.description:
Initially a frightened and orphaned hatchling, Lothrem has grown in a curious manner. Now a full-sized and fully capable ancient dragon, their wisdom and natural magic are mighty indeed, shaping their appearance and the very weather above their hidden Warrens lair.
More in tune with nature than a typical gold dragon, Lothrem has verdant green scales, and grass and flowers grow from their back and the outside of their wings.
They have elk-like antlers that wrap around their head, seeming to form a natural and regal crown. When they beat their wings, the air smells sweet like a forest glen, and bits of leaves and grass swirl about.
Unfortunately, the years of protection and isolation have not been kind to Lothrem, and for the last 500 years, they have been overcome with a bout of sadness and acute pain each day, resulting in a consistent drizzling rainfall above. Perhaps release, even a temporary one, from this gilded cage would resolve the matter, but the Circle is unwilling to break tradition and endanger the city.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 350 (Third Party)

The legends claim that seeing the coach is to court misfortune, and hearing your name uttered by the coachman is an instant death sentence, as he instructs you to board the carriage with the other damned passengers.
Undead Nature. A death coach doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 352 (Third Party)

monster.name: Durheim Initiate

trait.name: Spirit Hand
trait.text: The initiate can cast mage hand at will, requiring no verbal or somatic components. The initiate can cast this spell and control the hand as a bonus action, and when the initiate casts the spell, it can make the hand visible.

trait.name: Unarmored Defense
trait.text: While the initiate is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The initiate makes two attacks.

action.name: Spirit Strike
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +4 to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4+2) force damage.

action.name: Shortsword
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6+2) piercing damage.

monster.description:
Those who have only recently begun to follow the teachings of Attiskin are referred to as initiates. These individuals have begun to open their eyes to the wonders and dangers of the Ethereal, but they are only fledglings. Some of these inexperienced monks feel the call to Walk the Liminal Path earlier than is typicalâ€”these brave souls are destined to accomplish greatness or fall to tragedy.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 353 (Third Party)

monster.name: Durheim Guide

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
trait.text: The guide can see up to 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane.

trait.name: Evasion
trait.text: If the guide is subjected to an effect that allows. it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the guide instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Spirit Hand
trait.text: The guide can cast mage hand at will requiring no verbal or somatic components. The initiate can cast this spell and control the hand as a bonus action, and when the initiate casts the spell, it can make the hand invisible.

trait.name: Stunning Strike
trait.text: When the guide hits a creature with a melee attack, it can force the target to make a DC 13 Constituion saving throw. On a failed save, the target is stunned until the end of the guide's next turn.

trait.name: Supernatural Attacks
trait.text: The guide's weapon attacks are magical, and its Spirit Strike can hit targets on the Ethereal Plane.

trait.name: Unarmored Defense
trait.text: While the guide is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The guide makes three attacks.

action.name: Spirit Strike
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +5 to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) force damage.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Deflect MIssile
reaction.text: In response to being hit by a ranged weapon attack, the guide deflects the missile. The damage it takes from the attack is reduced by 18 (1d10+13). If the damage is reduced to 0, the guide catches the missile if it's small enough to hold in one hand and the guide has a hand free. It can then make a ranged weapon attack with the caught missile, which has an attack bonus of +5, a normal range of 20 feet, and a long range of 60 feet. On a hit, the target takes 6 (1d6+3) damage of the missile's type.

monster.description:
When Durheim monks have honed their soul to the point where the Walking the Liminal Path is the next stage of their destiny, they begin their journey as Guides.
Along the Path, they travel across the land and dutifully seek out struggling spirits. When they feel the time is right, they return to record their experiences. As the main body of the Monastery's membership, Guides are often someone's first introduction to the Order.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 353 (Third Party)

monster.name: Durheim Leader
monster.save: Str +5, Dex +8, Con +7, Int +5, Wis +9, Cha +6

trait.name: Evasion
trait.text: If the leader is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to only take half damage, the leader instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Invisibility
trait.text: As a bonus action, the leader can magically turn invisible until the start of its next turn, or until it makes an attack or casts a spell.

trait.name: Spirit Hand
trait.text: The leader can cast mage hand at will, requiring no verbal or somatic components. The leader can cast this spell and control the hand as a bonus action, and when the leader casts the spell, it can make the hand invisible.

trait.name: Stunning Strike
trait.text: When the leader hits a creature with a melee attack, it can force the target to make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target is stunned until the end of the leader's next turn.

trait.name: Supernatural Attacks
trait.text: The leader's weapon attacks are magical, and its Spirit Strike can hit targets on the Ethereal Plane.

trait.name: Unarmored Defense
trait.text: While the leader is wearing no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The leader makes four attacks.

action.name: Spirit Strike
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +9 to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (1d10+4) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d10+4) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Deflect MIssile
reaction.text: When the leader is hit by a ranged weapon attack, it deflects the missile, reducing the damage it takes from the attack by 26 (1d10+21). If the damage is reduced to 0, the leader catches the missile if it's small enough to hold in one hand and the leader has a hand free. It can then make a ranged weapon attack with the caught missile, which has an attack bonus of +8, a normal range of 20 feet, and a long range of 60 feet. On a hit, the target takes 9 (1d10+4) damage of the missile's type.

reaction.name: Phase
reaction.text: When the leader is hit by an attack, it partially slips into the Border Ethereal, reducing the damage it takes from the attack by 16 (2d10+5).

monster.description:
Within the walls and courtyards of Durheim Monastery, the Leader serves as spiritual and secular advisor. In this role, they give lectures and interpretations of Lightseer Attiskin's teachings and philosophies, and ensure that both the living and the dead can walk their respective paths safely.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 354 (Third Party)

The lightseer's gaze is a precious and heavily guarded artifact within Durheim Monastery, originally worn by Lightseer Attiskin. He left explicit provision that only in times of dire need should the mantle of Lightseer be taken up. Wearing the lightseer's gaze causes blindness, but the stars and celestial bodies in the heavens are still visible. The mysterious item also rewrites the Lightseer's history, forcing the bearer to select a new nameâ€”only the bearer is aware that they ever had a different name.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 354 (Third Party)

monster.name: Ghost Dragon
monster.resist: acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, prone, restrained

trait.name: Eternity
trait.text: The dragon can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The dragon can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance
trait.text: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The dragon can use its Horrifying Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Withering Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +12 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (2d10+6) necrotic damage plus 5 (1d10) cold damage.

action.name: Withering Claw
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +12 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d6+6) necrotic damage.

action.name: Withering Tail
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +12 to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d8+6) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrifying Presence
action.text: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or become frightened for 1 minute. If the save fails by 5 or more, the target also ages 1d4x10 years. A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the frightened condition on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Horrifying Presence for the next 24 hours. The aging effect can be reversed with a greater restoration spell, but only within 24 hours of it occuring.

action.name: Chilling Breath
action.text: The dragon exhales deathly cold energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 (18d6) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Legendary Actions
legendary.text: The dragon can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The dragon regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Detect
legendary.text: The dragon makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
legendary.text: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Etherealness (Costs 2 Actions)
legendary.text: The dragon eneters the Ethereeal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
legendary.text: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take 13 (2d6+6) necrotic damage and be knocked prone. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

monster.description:
In pursuit of knowledge or power, occasionally the soul of a chromatic dragon will accidentally or willfully ascend from its mortal trappings to terrorize the Ethereal Plane. Most often, a slain dragon will follow a pattern similar to other mortal creatures, becoming so consumed by the desire for vengeance that their incorporeal essence lingers. These vicious creatures are not to be underestimated upon observing their single-minded fury, for their bone-chilling breath weapon and life-sapping melee onslaught are truly formidable.
Undead Nature. A ghost dragon doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 355 (Third Party)

monster.name: Haunted Reflection
monster.languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained, unconscious

trait.name: Death Shift
trait.text: If damage reduces the reflect to 0 hit points, it can make a Constition saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is thunder or from a critical hit. The reflection automatically fails this saving throw if there are no other reflective surfaces within 60 feet of it. On a success, the reflection regains 10 hit points and uses its Mirror Step (no action required) as the previous reflexive surface that contained it is destroyed.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
trait.text: The reflection can magically communicate simple ideas, emotions and images telepathically with any creature within 100 feet of it that can understand a language.

trait.name: Unsettling Glare
trait.text:
When a creature that can see the reflection starts its turn within 60 feet of the reflection, the reflection can force the creature to make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw if the reflection isn't incapacitated. A target automatically succeeds on this saving throw if it can't be frightened. On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on ability checks and its speed is halved until the start of its next turn.
Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the reflection until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the reflection in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

action.name: Concentrated Ire
action.text: The reflection focuses a wave of psychic fury at one creature it can see within 120 feet of it. The target must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw, taking 18 (4d8) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that has averted its eyes from the reflection has advantage on this saving throw, and takes no damage if it succeeds on the save.

action.name: Mirror Step
action.text: The reflection teleports into another nonmagical, metallic reflective surface of its choice that it can see within 60 feet.

reaction.name: Magic Reflection
reaction.text: When the reflection is the only target of a spell or other magical effect that misses it or whose saving throw it succeeds, the reflection reflects the spell or effect back at its source. The source must be within 120 feet of the reflection or this effect fails. The reflection uses the spell save DC, attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the original source.

monster.description:
When an eminently-wrathful soul is murdered within view of a mirror, it can sometimes become trapped within. This haunted reflection can only interact with the material plane in a very limited fashion, but is dangerous nonetheless. With concentrated rage as it's weapon, it hunts those that it deems undeserving of life, that still possess the joy it no longer can. Those who wish to confront a reflection should be especially wary of using magic against it, lest they find themselves suffering from the rebounded spell. They should also take care to destroy other reflective surfaces nearby, lest it escape.
Undead Nature. A haunted reflection doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 356 (Third Party)

monster.name: The Wild Hunt
monster.resist: acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, poisoned, prone, restrained

trait.name: Hunter's Prowess
trait.text: The Wild Hunt have advantage on attack rolls against a target if they are occupying the same space as the target and there are no other hostille creatures in the Wild Hunt's space.

trait.name: Incorporeal Swarm
trait.text: The Wild Hunt can occupy another creature's space and vice-versa. The Wild Hunt can also move through the opening large enough for a Medium creature, and they can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. The Wild Hunt takes 5 (1d10) force damage if they end their turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
trait.text: The Wild Hunt have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The Wild Hunt make two mauling rent attacks. They can use their Volley in place of one attack.

action.name: Mauling Rend
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6+4) piercing damage plus 9 (2d4+4) slashing damage, or 7 (1d6+4) piercing damage plus 6 (1d4+4) slashing damage if the Wild Hunt have half their hit points or fewer.

action.name: Volley
action.text: The Wild Hunt releases a flurry of arrows, targeting a point they can see within 120 feet of them. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius, 20-foot-high cylinder centered on that point must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 (4d6) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the Wild Hunt have half their hit points or fewer, a target instead takes 7 (2d6) piercing damage on a failed save, or no damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Legendary Actions
legendary.text: The Wild Hunt can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Wild Hunt regain spent legendary actions at the start of their turn.

legendary.name: Move
legendary.text: The Wild Hunt moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Rallying Horn (below half hit points only)
legendary.text: The Wild Hunt regains 13 (2d12) temporary hit points.

legendary.name: War Horn (Costs 2 Actions)
legendary.text: Whenever a target takes damage from the Wild Hunt before the end of their next turn, the target takes an extra 4 (1d8) force damage.

monster.description:
Few countryside stories are more prevalent than that of The Wild Hunt. Composed of myriad spectral predators and fallen hunters, the hunt roam the woods of both the Material and Ethereal planes in search of a worthy quarry. Scholars have recorded only a few accounts of surviving eyewitnesses, who mutter and wail about the terrible, echoing horn calls and endlessly trampling feet.
Undead Nature. The Wild Hunt don't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 357 (Third Party)

monster.name: Ale Elemental
monster.resist: cold, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, drunkenness, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained, unconscious

trait.name: Alcohol Form
trait.text: The elemental can enter a hostille creature's space and stop there. it can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Freeze
trait.text: If the elemental takes cold damage, it partially freezes; its speed is reduced by 20 feet until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d8+4) bludgeoning damage plus 4 (1d8) poison damage.

action.name: Whelm
action.text:
Each creature in the elemental's space must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 13 (2d8+4) bludgeoning damage. If it is Large or smaller, it is also grappled (escape DC 14). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained and unable to breathe unless it can breathe water. If the saving throw is successful, the target is pushed out of the elemental's space.
The elemental can grapple one Large creature or up to two Medium or smaller creatures at one time. At the start of each of the elemental's turns, each target grappled by it takes 8 (1d8+4) bludgeoning damage plus 4 (1d8) poison damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or gain one level of drunkenness. A creature within 5 feet of the elemental can pull a creature or object out of it by taking an action to make a DC 14 Strength check and succeeding. Any levels of drunkenness caused by this effect go away when the grapple ends.

monster.description:
These swirling and frothy, caramel-colored creatures smell of honey and hops. The existence of ale elementals has brought about hours of intense research and debate about the possibility of an elemental plane of alcohol or the like. Planar travel has thus far proved impossible, although these elementals are occasionally summoned by inebriated mages purposefully or accidentally. Regardless of their means of arrival, these creatures swarm towards areas with high concentrations of alcoholic beverages. As they pursue their murky agendas, they usually end up causing terrible havoc and general mayhem.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 358 (Third Party)

monster.name: Wine Elemental
monster.resist: cold, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, drunkenness, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained, unconscious

trait.name: Alcohol Form
trait.text: The elemental can enter a hostille creature's space and stop there. it can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Partial Freeze
trait.text: If the elemental takes 10 cold damage or more during a single turn, it partially freezes; its speed is reduced by 20 feet until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d8+4) bludgeoning damage plus 4 (1d8) poison damage.

action.name: Whelm
action.text:
Each creature in the elemental's space must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 13 (2d8+4) bludgeoning damage. If it is Large or smaller, it is also grappled (escape DC 14). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained and unable to breathe unless it can breathe water. If the saving throw is successful, the target is pushed out of the elemental's space.
The elemental can grapple one Large creature or up to two Medium or smaller creatures at one time. At the start of each of the elemental's turns, each target grappled by it takes 8 (1d8+4) bludgeoning damage plus 4 (1d8) poison damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw and gain one level of drunkenness or gain two level of drunkenness on a failure.
A creature within 5 feet of the elemental can pull a creature or object out of it by taking an action to make a DC 14 Strength check and succeeding. Any levels of drunkenness caused by this effect go away when the grapple ends.

monster.description:
Taking the form of bubbling liquids of various colors, wine elementals are a more potent and rare version of the ale elemental. More intelligent and attuned to nature than their fellows, their appearance is usually in reaction to the destruction of nature. Bacchanalian parties that damage the environment often attract their ire, resulting in many party-goers getting far more than they reckoned. Whatever their perceived or actual motivations, these elementals are a formidable force and especially dangerous for those with a low tolerance for alcohol.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 358 (Third Party)

monster.name: Festus Battlechef

trait.name: Divine Strike
trait.text: When the battlechef hits a creature with a weapon attack, the battlechef can cause the attack to deal an extra 4 (1d8) acid or poison damage (battlechef's choice) to the target.

trait.name: Poison Resilience
trait.text: The battlechef has advantage on saving throws against poison.

trait.name: Spellcasting
trait.text:
The battlechef is an 8th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 14 +6 to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:
Cantrips (at will): guidance, mending, sacred flame, thaumaturgy 1st level (4 slots): bless, goodberry, purify food and drink 2nd level (3 slots): heat metal, protection from poison, spiritual weapon 3rd level (3 slots): create food and water, mass healing word, stinking cloud 4th level (2 slots): blight, control water

trait.name: Strong Stomach
trait.text: While the battlechef is drunk, it can choose to magically suppress the alcohol's effects for 1 minute.

action.name: Handaxe
action.text: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft. or 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) slashing damage.

action.name: Create Healing Draft
action.text: The battlechef creates a magical potion in its free hand or at its feet (battlechef's choice). A creature that drinks this potion regains 15 (2d6+8) hit points. The potion turns to dust and is lost if the battlechef finishes a short or long rest before it is consumed.

reaction.name: Table-Turner
reaction.text: When the battlechef is hit by an attack from a creature within 5 feet of it, the creature must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 6 (1d12) poison damage and is poisoned until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't poisoned.

monster.spells: guidance, mending, sacred flame, thaumaturgy, bless, goodberry, purify food and drink, heat metal, protection from poison, spiritual weapon, create food and water, mass healing word, stinking cloud, blight, control water
monster.description:
A veteran of both cuisine and combat, the battlechef is a devout warrior and an exemplary cook. Renowned for their magical prowess and strength of will, a battlechef goes where their deity and culinary sense of purpose lead. They are found most often behind the bar, within the bustling kitchen, slicing through enemies, or providing much-needed succor to those in need.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 359 (Third Party)

monster.name: Purple Jam
monster.resist: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, prone

trait.name: Amorphous
trait.text: The jam can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the jam remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a mass of grape jam.

trait.name: Limited Spell Resistance
trait.text: The jam has advantage on saving throws against spells of 1 st level or lower.

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The jam regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the jam takes necrotic damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the jam's next turn.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
trait.text: If the jam dies, it regains all its hit points and becomes active again in 24 hours unless its remains are eaten, destroyed or targeted by a dispel magic spell.

action.name: Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6+1) bludgeoning damage plus 3 (1d6) poison damage.

monster.description:
A small and yet pernicious ooze, the purple jam looks like a mushy globule of smashed grapes or dark berries. They mindlessly consume plantlife, leading some to speculate that they originated from a goodberry spell gone wrong. Their wanderings often lead them to spaces like taverns where their natural camouflage is uniquely suited, and food is plentiful. A persistent creature, it's surprisingly difficult to destroyâ€”especially for the type of magical practitioners typically found in the small towns and cities they prefer.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 360 (Third Party)

monster.name: Mimic Keg

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The mimic can use its action to polymorph into a keg, mug, vat or other alcohol-related object or back into its true amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form, except when it polymorphs into an object, it can choose to change its size to Tiny or Small until it polymorphs back into its true form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It revers to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Adhesive (Object Form Only)
trait.text: The mimic adheres to anything that touches it. A huge or smaller creature adhered to the mimic is also grappled by it (escape DC 13). Ability checks made to escape the grapple has disadvantage.

trait.name: False Appearance (Object Form Only)
trait.text: While the mimic remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary alcohol-related object.

trait.name: Grappler
trait.text: The mimic has advantage on attack rolls against any creature grappled by it.

action.name: Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) bludgeoning damage. If the mimic is in object form, the target is subjected to its adhesive trait.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage plus 4 (1d8) poison damage.

monster.description:
Although most mimics are known for their ability to transform into innocuous items, mimic kegs are a particular cousin that transform solely into alcohol-related objects. Scholars believe that long-term exposure to alcoholic drinks gradually morphed a number of ancient mimics into this unique breed. Most mimics are ambush predators, but mimic kegs are particularly patient hunters. When plagued by these monsters, some taverns develop an almost religious inventory system to ensure their mugs, jugs, and kegs are safe for customers.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 361 (Third Party)

monster.name: Refuse Golem
monster.immune: poison, psychic, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the golem remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary pile of garbage.

trait.name: Immutable Form
trait.text: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
trait.text: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
trait.text: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Stench
trait.text: Any creature other than a refuse golem that starts its turn within 10 feet of the golem, must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned until the start of the creature's next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all refuse golems for 1 hour.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8+4) bludgeoning damage plus 9 (2d8) piercing or slashing damage (golem's choice)

action.name: Hurl Junk
action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. Hit: 26 (4d10+4) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Missile Absorption
reaction.text: When the golem is hit by a ranged weapon attack, it absorbs the projectile into its form. When it does so, the damage it takes from the attack is reduced by 11 (2d10). A creature within 5 feet of the golem can take an action to pull an absorbed projectile out of it with a successful DC 15 Strength check.

monster.description:
Many speak of trash becoming treasure, but trash is lifeblood for the refuse golem. Most common in areas with large amounts of magical food and drink, these beasts form when mounds of partially consumed waste are not disposed of properly. The resulting magical landfill develops an aggressive, sentient construct that is formidable in battle, most known for their poisonous stench and amorphous defenses.
Source: The Griffon's Saddlebag: Book Two p. 361 (Third Party)
